sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Bangladesh is a South Asian country located on the Bay of Bengal, known for its fertile delta, vibrant culture, and resilience in the face of natural challenges.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Dhaka is the capital and largest city of Bangladesh, serving as its political, cultural, and economic hub.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Bangladeshi taka (BDT).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Bengali (Bangla), written in its own script and spoken by the vast majority of the population.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Popular dishes include biryani, hilsa fish curry, panta bhat (fermented rice), and sweets like roshogolla and sandesh.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Bangladesh is dominated by the Ganges-Brahmaputra Delta, with fertile plains, rivers, and mangrove forests like the Sundarbans, home to the Bengal tiger.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Bangladeshi culture emphasizes literature, music, art, and festivals. The Bengali language movement and traditions of poetry and song are central to national identity.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Sundarbans mangrove forest, Cox’s Bazar (the world’s longest natural sea beach), Srimangal tea gardens, and historic Dhaka landmarks.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: The national anthem of Bangladesh, 'Amar Sonar Bangla,' was written by Rabindranath Tagore, who also composed India’s anthem.

history.event: The Bengal region was home to ancient kingdoms like Vanga and later part of the Maurya and Gupta Empires.
The Delhi Sultanate established Muslim rule in Bengal, influencing culture and architecture.
The Mughal Empire incorporated Bengal, making Dhaka a major provincial capital and trade hub.
The Battle of Plassey marked the beginning of British colonial rule in Bengal.
The Partition of Bengal by the British sparked nationalist movements and protests.
Following the partition of India, East Bengal became East Pakistan, part of the newly created Pakistan.
The Bengali Language Movement saw protests demanding recognition of Bengali as a state language, leading to eventual success.
The Bangladesh Liberation War led to independence from Pakistan, with support from India.
Bangladesh adopted its constitution and became a parliamentary democracy.
Bangladesh transitioned back to parliamentary democracy after years of military rule.
Sheikh Hasina became Prime Minister, ushering in a period of economic growth and development.
